journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of the American Heart Association: Cardiovascular and Cerebrovascular Disease

title-group.article-title: Trends and Factors Associated With Peripheral Vascular Interventions for the Treatment of Claudication From 2011 to 2022: A National Medicare Cohort Study
title-group.alt-title: PVI Trends for Treatment of Claudication

aff.institution: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine

aff.named-content: Division of Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, Department of Surgery

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Previous cross‐sectional studies have identified wide practice pattern variations in the use of peripheral vascular interventions (PVIs) for the treatment of claudication. However, there are limited data on longitudinal practice patterns. We aimed to describe the temporal trends and charges associated with PVI use for claudication over the past 12 years in the United States.

sec.title: Methods and Results
sec.p: We conducted a retrospective analysis using 100% Medicare fee‐for‐service claims data to identify all patients who underwent a PVI for claudication between January 2011 and December 2022. We evaluated the trends in utilization and Medicare‐allowed charges of PVI according to anatomic level, procedure type, and intervention settings using generalized linear models. Multinomial logistic regressions were used to evaluate factors associated with different levels and types of PVI. We identified 599 197 PVIs performed for claudication. The proportional use of tibial PVI increased 1.0% per year, and atherectomy increased by 1.6% per year over the study period. The proportion of PVIs performed in ambulatory surgical centers/office‐based laboratories grew at 4% per year from 12.4% in 2011 to 55.7% in 2022. Total Medicare‐allowed charges increased by $11 980 035 USD/year. Multinomial logistic regression identified significant associations between race and ethnicity and treatment setting with use of both atherectomy and tibial PVI.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The use of tibial PVI and atherectomy for the treatment of claudication has increased dramatically in in ambulatory surgical center/office‐based laboratory settings, non‐White patients, and resulting in a significant increase in health care charges. There is a critical need to improve the delivery of value‐based care for the treatment of claudication.

fn.p: This article was sent to Amgad Mentias, MD, Associate Editor, for review by expert referees, editorial decision, and final disposition.
For Sources of Funding and Disclosures, see page 12.

def.p: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

list-item.p: This study is the most up‐to‐date analysis describing the use of peripheral vascular intervention for claudication using longitudinal, nationally representative data.

The use of tibial peripheral vascular intervention and atherectomy for the treatment of claudication has increased dramatically in the past decade, despite poor evidence supporting their efficacy, especially long term.
There is a critical need to improve the delivery of equitable, evidence‐based, and value‐based care for the treatment of claudication.

body.p: An estimated 6.5 million people aged 40 and older were living with diagnosed peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the United States in 2021. 1 Among this population, approximately 10% to 35% have claudication, a disabling condition that causes pain with exercise. 2 Although the gold standard treatment for claudication is best medical therapy, including prescription of antiplatelet agents, statins, smoking cessation, and supervised exercise therapy, a proportion of patients will receive invasive interventions. 3 The most common invasive revascularization for claudication is now endovascular peripheral vascular interventions (PVIs), which have overtaken open surgical revascularization procedures in the past 2 decades. Endovascular PVI is now the most common first‐line invasive procedure in adults with claudication. 4

Recently, concerns have been raised about the potential overuse of PVI for the treatment of claudication. 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 In patients who are not first optimally managed via conservative approaches, PVI may be considered low‐value care or clinically unnecessary. We have previously demonstrated higher rates of repeat PVIs, accelerated PAD progression, and higher risk of major amputation in patients managed with early PVI compared with early conservative therapy for claudication, with highest risk among adults treated with atherectomy compared with other endovascular technologies. 8 , 9 Therefore, among patients who are not optimally managed via conservative approaches, PVI may be low value, medically unnecessary, or even harmful. Low‐value PVI not only exposes patients to unnecessary risks but also diverts critical resources away from more effective treatments for PAD.

Previous cross‐sectional studies using data from the VQI (Vascular Quality Initiative) registry have shown wide practice pattern variations in the use of PVI for the treatment of claudication. However, the VQI is limited to voluntarily participating institutions and, thus, we lack nationally representative data on longitudinal practice patterns and related health care expenditures. 10 The objective of this study was to describe the temporal trends and Medicare‐allowed charges associated with PVI use for claudication over the past 12 years in the United States and evaluate the factors associated with PVI for treating claudication.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: All data and materials have been made publicly available and can be accessed at https://resdac.org.

sec.title: Data Source and Study Population
sec.p: This was a retrospective analysis using 100% Medicare fee‐for‐service claims data accessed via the US Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Virtual Research Data Center. We identified all patients who underwent a PVI for claudication between January 1, 2011 and December 31, 2022 using Current Procedural Terminology codes (Table S1). PVI involving drug‐coated balloons and intravascular lithotripsy could not be distinguished from traditional balloon angioplasty in this analysis. Patients with claudication were identified using International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision (ICD‐9) and Tenth Revision (ICD‐10) codes based on previous studies 11 , 12 , 13 (Table S2). We excluded patients without 12 months of continuous enrollment in Medicare before their index PVI (n=101 738), of age <18 years (n=13), and those missing demographic information (n=321). Patients with any diagnosis of acute limb ischemia (n=651 215), or chronic limb‐threatening ischemia (n=1 764 509) within 12 months before their index PVI procedure were also excluded (Table S2). Approval was obtained from the Johns Hopkins Medicine Institutional Review Board. Medicare data were analyzed in a retrospective manner and consent was not required.

sec.title: Patient Characteristics
sec.p: We obtained patient demographic information including age, sex, race, and ZIP code of residence from the Medicare Master Beneficiary Summary File. 14 ZIP codes were mapped to a Federal Information Processing Standard code using the sashelp.zipcode file (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). The Federal Information Processing Standard code was then mapped to a core‐based statistical area code using a core‐based statistical area to Federal Information Processing Standard County Crosswalk from the National Bureau of Economic Research. 15 Core‐based statistical area codes were used to determine whether the patient's place of residence was metropolitan (urban core of ≥50 000 population) or micropolitan (a nonmetropolitan/rural area with <50 000 population). 7 The census region of residence were drawn based on home ZIP code according to national geographic regions. 16 For each patient who underwent a PVI for claudication, we reviewed all inpatient, outpatient, and carrier claims in the 12 months preceding the date of the procedure in order to identify comorbidities, including end‐stage kidney disease, diabetes, hypertension, and smoking history. Comorbidities status was based on a single inpatient diagnosis claim or at least 2 outpatient diagnosis claims >30 days apart. We obtained place of service codes to categorize the site of service where a PVI was performed.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The main outcome for the study was the use of PVI for claudication over time, evaluated by anatomic level, PVI type, and site of service. We categorized anatomic level as iliac, femoropopliteal, and tibial. We categorized procedure type as isolated angioplasty, isolated stent, isolated atherectomy, or stent with atherectomy, based on the Current Procedural Terminology codes (Table S1). PVI of the same type occurring at the same anatomic level on the same day were considered to be 1 procedure. PVIs at multiple levels on the same day were considered separate procedures. Site of service was categorized as ambulatory surgical center or office‐based laboratory (ASC/OBL) or hospital (inpatient or outpatient or other). 17

We also examined the relationship between the trends in PVI use and Medicare‐allowed charges and evaluated patient characteristics associated with use of different levels and types of PVI. Medicare‐allowed charges is the total payment allowed for the service from a professional claim and includes both the Medicare and patient‐paid amount. 18

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Sample demographic, clinical, and procedural characteristics were reported as mean±SE (estimated using the sandwich [robust] estimator) or median (interquartile range) for normally and nonnormally distributed continuous variables, respectively, and as proportions for categorical variables. We plotted the number and the proportion of PVI by level, type, and site of service overall and by year. Chi‐square tests were used to compare differences between categorical variables, and Cochran–Mantel–Haenszel trends tests were used to compare within‐category differences over time. Univariate multinomial logistic regression analyses were used to identify individual factors associated with the level of PVI and type of PVI, separately. We calculated the variance inflation factor and checked tolerance values to ensure there was no collinearity between covariates. We tested the linearity assumption for year by performing a linear regression analysis and plotting the results visually. A multilevel multivariate multinomial logistic regression was then used to identify factors associated with each outcome after controlling for patient demographic characteristics (age, sex, race, ethnicity, population density, region of residence), comorbidities (end‐stage kidney disease, diabetes, hypertension, and smoking history), site of service, and year that the intervention was performed using an a priori approach. Relative risk ratios were used to report associations among patient characteristics, site of service, and geographic factors according to anatomic levels and PVI types. All multivariable models were clustered by patient to account for the fact that each individual patient may have contributed to multiple observations. Generalized linear regression models with a Gaussian distribution were used to assess the associations of level of PVI, type of PVI, and Medicare‐allowed charge amount for calendar year in order to understand the crude (unadjusted) change in Medicare‐allowed charges over time. Statistical significance was set at P<0.05 for all analyses. Statistical analyses were performed using Joinpoint (https://surveillance.cancer.gov/joinpoint/) and SAS Enterprise Version 7.1 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC).

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: A total of 599 197 PVIs were performed on 316 183 patients over the course of the 12‐year study period. The median (interquartile range) age at the time of intervention was 73.7 years (interquartile range 68.6–79.5 years). The majority of patients undergoing PVI were male (58.1%), non‐Hispanic White (80.7%), diagnosed with hypertension (66.0%), residing in urban areas (78.6%), and most commonly located in the South (48.6%) (Table 1). The overall number of PVIs increased from 2011 to 2014, dipped until 2016, resumed growth until 2019, and then declined again through 2022 (Figure 1).

caption.p: Characteristics of Medicare Patients Who Underwent Endovascular PVIs for Claudication Between 2011 and 2022

fn.p: ASC/OBL indicates ambulatory surgical center or office‐based laboratory; and PVI, peripheral vascular intervention.
Other includes American Indian or Alaska Native

caption.title: Number of PVI performed for claudication per year in the Medicare population, 2011 to 2022.
caption.p: APC indicates annual percentage change; and PVI, peripheral vascular interventions.

sec.title: Anatomic Level of PVI
sec.p: Overall, the majority (54.6%) of PVIs for claudication were performed at the femoropopliteal level, followed by the iliac (27.0%), and tibial (18.4%) levels. Among the PVIs involving a tibial intervention, 63% were conducted concurrently with another procedure, either at the iliac or femoropopliteal level. Nine percent of PVIs included concomitant iliac and femoropopliteal interventions, and 1% of PVIs included treatment of all 3 anatomic levels during the same procedure. Over the 12‐year study period, the femoropopliteal PVI rate remained consistent (53.2%–55.7%), whereas the iliac PVI rate decreased from 32.4% in 2011 to 22.3% in 2022, and the tibial PVI rate increased from 13.2% in 2010 to 23.3% in 2022 (Figure 2A). The mean increase in tibial PVI for claudication was 1.0% per year (95% CI, 0.8%–1.2%).

caption.title: Proportion of PVI performed for claudication per year according to anatomic level (A) and PVI type (B).
caption.p: A, Blue=iliac PVI, green=femoropopliteal PVI, gray=tibial PVI. B, Blue=angioplasty, Green=atherectomy, gray=stent, pink=stent atherectomy. PVI indicates peripheral vascular interventions.

sec.p: Multilevel multinomial logistic regression was performed to evaluate factors associated with level of PVI (Table 2). After adjustment, there were significant differences in the use of iliac and tibial PVI compared with femoropopliteal PVI, according to patient age, sex, race, comorbidities, geographic location factors, and site of service. Iliac PVIs were more common in younger (<65 years old), female, White patients with end‐stage kidney disease, hypertension, and smoking history, and more frequently performed in hospital settings. In contrast, tibial PVIs were more common in older (>65 years old), male, non‐White patients with diabetes, and more frequently performed in ASC/OBL settings.

caption.p: Multinomial Logistic Regression Models Assessing Patient Characteristics Associated With Anatomic Level of PVIs Performed for Claudication in the Medicare Population, 2011 to 2022

fn.p: ASC/OBL indicates ambulatory surgical center or office‐based laboratory; ESKD, end‐stage kidney disease; and PVI, peripheral vascular intervention.

sec.title: Type of PVI
sec.p: Overall, the most common type of PVI used for treating claudication was an isolated stent (32.7%), followed by isolated atherectomy (29.7%), angioplasty (27.1%), and stent with atherectomy (10.5%). Over the 12‐year study period, the rate of isolated stent use decreased from 44.6% in 2011 to 22.6% in 2022, whereas the atherectomy rate increased from 19.9% to 37.2%, and the use of stent with atherectomy increased from 7.1% to 11.7% (Figure 2B). The use of atherectomy significantly increased over time, at a rate of a 1.6% per year (95% CI, 1.4%–1.8%).

Multilevel multinomial logistic regression was performed to evaluate factors associated with type of PVI (Table 3). Isolated atherectomy and atherectomy with stenting were more commonly used in male, non‐White patients, and more frequently used in ASC/OBL settings. Isolated atherectomy was more commonly used to treat older patients with diabetes, whereas atherectomy with stenting was used to treat younger patients with a smoking history. In contrast, isolated stenting was used more commonly in younger, female, White patients with hypertension and smoking and more frequently used in hospital settings.

caption.p: Multinomial Logistic Regression Models Assessing Patient Characteristics Associated With Type of PVI Performed for Claudication in the Medicare Population, 2011 to 2022

fn.p: ASC/OBL indicates ambulatory surgical center or office‐based laboratory; ESRD, end‐stage renal disease; and PVI, peripheral vascular intervention.

sec.title: Site of Service
sec.p: Overall, the majority of PVIs were performed in hospital settings (62.8%) rather than ASC/OBLs (37.3%). Over the 12‐year study period, the proportion of PVIs performed in ASC/OBLs increased significantly: a minority of PVIs (12.4%) were performed in ASC/OBLs in 2011, which became the majority (55.7%) in 2022, which is equivalent to an increase of 4.0% per year (95% CI, 3.5%–4.5%; Figure 3). In 2011, cardiologists performed 57.0% of all PVIs, but by 2022, this percentage had decreased to 47.0%. On the other hand, vascular surgeons saw an increase in their involvement, with their PVI contribution rising from 22.9% in 2011 to 33.4% in 2022 (Figure 4).

caption.title: Proportion of PVI performed for claudication per year according to site of service.
caption.p: Blue=hospital, Green=ambulatory surgical center or office‐based laboratory. PVI indicates peripheral vascular interventions.

caption.title: Proportion of PVI performed for claudication per year according to physician specialty.
caption.p: Blue=cardiology, pink=vascular surgery, gray=radiology, green=other. PVI indicates peripheral vascular interventions.

sec.title: Medicare‐Allowed Charges
sec.p: The total Medicare‐allowed charges for PVIs performed for claudication from 2011 to 2022 was $2 195 550 390, equivalent to a mean±SD of $3664.15±6.44 per procedure (Figure 5A). There was an absolute increase of $11 980 035 (95% CI, $4557180–$19 402 891) USD charged for PVIs performed for claudication per year. For every 1% increase in atherectomy use, Medicare‐allowed charges increased by $8 244 902 (95% CI, $4476520–$12 013 284) USD. For every 1% increase in tibial PVI use, Medicare‐allowed charges increased by $11 887 745 (95% CI, $5145383–$18 630 107) USD.

caption.title: Medicare‐allowed charges per year associated with PVI performed for claudication, overall (A) and by PVI type (B).
caption.p: Blue=angioplasty, green=atherectomy, gray=stent, pink=stent atherectomy. APC indicates annual percentage change; and PVI, peripheral vascular interventions.

sec.p: On a per‐procedure basis, the Medicare‐allowed charges for atherectomy increased from $2660±40.34 per procedure in 2011 to a peak of $8256±38.09 per procedure in 2019, after which there was a decline to $6931±32.83 per procedure in 2022 (Figure 5B). The Medicare‐allowed charges for stent with atherectomy increased from $4807±105.78 per procedure in 2011 to a peak of $12 377±81.75 per procedure in 2019, after which there was a decline to $10 190±71.25 per procedure in 2022. The Medicare allowed‐charges for isolated angioplasty ($1045±3.42 USD) and isolated stent placement ($1390±5.03 USD) remained relatively stable over time.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: In our study of 599 197 PVI procedures performed in Medicare beneficiaries with claudication, we found that tibial PVI and atherectomy have become increasingly prevalent in the treatment of claudication and have shifted from the hospital setting to ASC/OBL settings. Overall, the Medicare‐allowed charges associated with PVIs are substantial and increasing over time. To the best of our knowledge, our study is the most up‐to‐date analysis describing the use of PVI for claudication using longitudinal, nationally representative data.

The appropriateness of invasive interventions performed for claudication depends on the anatomic level of disease. Based on the recent Society for Vascular Surgery Appropriateness Use Criteria for the management of claudication, 3 endovascular revascularization as initial or postsupervised exercise therapy may be appropriate for some patients with severe lifestyle limiting symptoms in the setting of aortoiliac disease. Similarly, femoropopliteal PVI may be an appropriate intervention for femoropopliteal disease causing lifestyle limiting symptoms after a trial (and failure) of exercise therapy. However, in both the 2015 Society for Vascular Surgery professional clinical guidelines 19 and the more recent appropriateness use criteria, 3 tibial interventions for the treatment of claudication are considered to pose a greater risk than benefit and are not indicated in any setting. Despite this, we found an increasing trend in the use of tibial PVIs from 2011 through 2022, with an overall increase of 12% over the past 12 years. Notably, tibial PVIs were more common in adults with diabetes, which may reflect an increased prevalence of infrapopliteal disease caused by diabetic atherosclerosis, 20 and in high‐reimbursement (ie, ASC/OBL) settings, which may reflect the policy change from the CMS that resulted in higher reimbursement rates for these procedures. Both findings are consistent with previously reported associations of tibial PVIs performed for claudication. 5 , 7 , 21

Of all PVI types we investigated, the use of isolated atherectomy increased the most over the past 12 years. This raises concerns because multiple prior meta‐analyses have failed to show significant benefits associated with atherectomy compared with balloon angioplasty for the treatment of PAD. 22 , 23 , 24 Other studies have suggested possible harms associated with atherectomy, including shorter time to claudication recurrence, more repeat procedures, and a higher rate of conversion to chronic limb‐threatening ischemia, when used in the setting of claudication. 8 , 25 , 26 Despite a lack of clear evidence supporting the long‐term efficacy of atherectomy over other available technologies, its use increased by 1.6% per year. This temporal change is also concerning due to the high costs associated with atherectomy. Previous studies have shown that the majority of Medicare reimbursements for index femoropopliteal PVIs were attributable to atherectomy 7 and that atherectomy procedures are often more costly than alternative treatments such as angioplasty or stenting. 27 We found that atherectomy, on average, was associated with charges that are 5 to 6 times higher than those associated with angioplasty, with or without a stent.

Disparities in the treatments offered to White and non‐White patients have been documented for decades. Our study adds to this literature in finding that, among patients with claudication, non‐White patients were more likely to receive a tibial PVI or an atherectomy to treat their disease. Notably, for claudication, both tibial PVI and atherectomy are considered low‐value procedures that should not be used routinely, 28 The current study adds to our previous work where we demonstrated that Black patients have significantly higher odds of receiving an early (within 6 months) PVI for claudication compared with White patients after controlling for geographic factors and county income. 29 Black adults undergo more PVIs than White adults at a population level and experience more adverse outcomes, including major amputation or death. 30 Taken together, these findings raise concerns for health equity and highlight the need for further investigation into the underlying factors contributing to these disparities. It is important to address these disparities in the use of elective PVI to ensure all patients receive appropriate and equitable care. Potential efforts to mitigate these differences include improving access to comprehensive health care services for non‐White patients, providing cultural competence training for health care workers, and considering alternative treatments to low‐value PVI. 31 , 32

There was a clear shift in the site of service at which PVIs were performed over the course of our 12‐year study period. In 2011, the majority of PVIs for claudication were performed in hospital settings, and by 2022, the majority were performed in ASC/OBL settings. This shift is unsurprising, as it followed a policy change that occurred in 2008. In an effort to reduce the health care costs of outpatient services, the CMS increased reimbursement for procedures performed in nonhospital settings. 33 The policy change intentionally incentivized the shift of PAD care from hospitals to outpatient settings, such as ASCs and OBLs. Early evidence of this shift was previously reported using Medicare fee‐for‐service data from 2006 through 2011 and showed that the rate of PVIs declined in inpatient settings and expanded in outpatient hospitals and office‐based clinics. 34 Even a decade ago, PVI for PAD was most commonly performed in outpatient hospital settings. Our data show efficacy of the CMS policy change on this prior information and shows efficacy of the CMS policy change in effectively moving PVI for claudication out of hospital settings. Our study also shows significant increases in the prevalence of tibial PVI and atherectomy use in the treatment of claudication in high‐reimbursement (ie, ASC/OBL) settings. It is possible that the CMS’ goal to move PVI out of the hospital setting inadvertently resulted in overuse of certain interventions.

In this study, we also observed notable shifts in the transition in physician specialties in performing PVIs, with a discernible increase in involvement from vascular surgeons compared with cardiologists and interventional radiologists. This shift underscores the evolving landscape of vascular care and the changing roles of different medical specialties in addressing PAD. One notable paradox highlighted in our findings was the discrepancy between the increasing trends in certain procedures, such as infrapopliteal revascularization, and the limited evidence supporting their long‐term clinical efficacy. Despite the rising use of infrapopliteal interventions in the treatment of claudication, there remains a paucity of long‐term clinical data demonstrating their effectiveness. 28 , 35 This paradox emphasizes a potential disconnect between clinical practice guidelines and appropriate use criteria with daily clinical practice.

Importantly, our study demonstrated an overall increasing trend of PVI used to treat claudication and increasing costs associated with this trend. We found an increase in Medicare‐allowed charges for claudication totaling nearly $12 million USD per year. The Medicare‐allowed charges associated with atherectomy for claudication more than doubled over the past 12 years. The economic burden of PVI for claudication seems unsustainable, and the high costs associated with PVI can contribute to financial burdens for patients and their families as well as health care system inefficiencies. 6 To address this issue, physicians and policymakers can promote evidence‐based practice and clinical guidelines for the management of claudication. 36 The Society for Vascular Surgery Appropriate Use Criteria is one means to accomplish this, although the influence on practice patterns in the treatment of claudication remain to be determined. Additionally, improving patient education about the risks and benefits of treatment options, and incentivizing health care providers to prioritize conservative treatment options and value‐based care, could help reduce the use of PVI in the management of claudication. It is important to emphasize that PVI should generally be reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative and medical therapies, without making blanket assumptions about the appropriateness of all PVIs for claudication.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study has several limitations. The results are based on Medicare beneficiaries primarily aged 65 years and older, which might not be representative of the overall US population with claudication. Administrative claims data are designed primarily for billing purposes and may not capture complete patient information or health conditions, which may result in residual confounding. Specifically, there is no way to identify the degree of patient symptoms or extent of anatomic disease using claims data. There is also a possibility that patients we identified as having claudication had more advanced PAD and were misclassified. However, we have recently demonstrated that the accuracy of using claims data to identify patients with claudication in Medicare data is high (81.3%). 35 Drug‐coated technology (balloons and stents) and intravascular lithotripsy are billed using the same Current Procedural Terminology codes as standard therapies, so we were not able to distinguish between them. We were unable to evaluate temporal trends in the medical management of claudication, as aspirin and supervised exercise therapy are frequently recommended by physicians without a documented prescription. We also did not evaluate patient outcomes in this analysis; the aim of this study was focused on temporal practice patterns in the treatment of claudication. We have reported patient‐based outcomes after PVI for claudication in prior work. 8 , 9 Finally, we observed a fluctuating trend in the total number of PVIs performed each year from 2011 to 2022. It is important to consider the potential impact of changes in Current Procedural Terminology codes on these trends and whether the decrease in procedural volume observed in the later years could be attributed to the effects of COVID‐19. It is also important to note that we do not report the number of patients with claudication as a denominator in our results because we performed a procedure‐level (rather than patient‐level) analysis. It is possible that some of the trends we report are related to an aging population with an increased prevalence of risk factors rather than practice‐specific changes alone.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The use of tibial PVI and atherectomy for the treatment of claudication has increased dramatically in the past decade, despite poor evidence supporting their efficacy, especially long term. This trend is most notable in ASC/OBL settings and among non‐White patients and has been associated with a significant increase in health care expenditures over time. Although some of these changes may be related to an aging population, there is a critical need to improve the delivery of equitable, evidence‐based, and value‐based care for the treatment of claudication.

sec.title: Sources of Funding
sec.p: None.
